title: How to Increase Red Blood Cell Count

steps.title: Incorporate iron-rich food in your diet for nutritional improvement.
steps.content: Incorporate iron-rich food in your diet for nutritional improvement. This will help the body replace what is lacking. Daily intake of iron-rich food will help increase red blood cells (RBCs) in the body. This is because iron is an essential part of a red blood cell and hemoglobin, since it helps deliver oxygen to different parts of the body. [2] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source It also helps excrete carbon monoxide upon exhalation. Food rich in iron includes: [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Beans/legumes (like lentils and peas) Dark leafy greens (like kale and spinach) Dried fruits (like prunes and raisins) Red meat (like beef and liver) Poultry Fish/shellfish Eggs Iron-fortified cereals and breads If you don’t get enough iron from food, ask your healthcare provider about taking supplements to increase your red blood cell production. [4] X Research source Iron is available in 50-200 mg tablets and may be taken 2-3 times daily. [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Get more copper.
steps.content: Get more copper. Copper is another essential mineral that helps the cells access the chemical form of iron necessary for red blood cells during the process of iron metabolism. Copper can be found in turkey, shellfish, liver, whole grains, chocolate, beans, figs, and nuts. [6] X Research source Copper supplements are also available in 1,700 mcg tablet form and can be taken once daily. [7] X Research source According to the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) adults require 900 mg of copper per day. [8] X Research source During the reproductive years, women require more copper than men due to blood loss during menstruation. [9] X Trustworthy Source Health.gov Online collection of health and fitness standards set by the U.S. Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion Go to source

steps.title: Make sure you get enough folic acid.
steps.content: Make sure you get enough folic acid. Otherwise known as vitamin B9, folic acid helps in the production of normal RBCs. A significant decrease folic acid may predispose anemia. [10] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Cereal, bread, dark green leafy vegetables, peas, lentils, beans, and nuts contain high amounts of folic acid. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It is also available in supplement form, usually ranging from 400 to 800 mcg. [12] X Research source The National Institute of Health recommends 400 mcg of folic acid per day for adult women and 600 mcg of folic acid per day for pregnant women. You can get folic acid in a multivitamin or prenatal vitamin. [13] X Research source Besides building healthy blood cells, studies show that folic acid plays an essential role in the production and repair of DNA. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Take vitamin A (retinol).
steps.content: Take vitamin A (retinol). Vitamin A may support stem cell development of red blood cells (RBCs) by allowing the body to metabolize enough iron to produce hemoglobin. Sweet potatoes, carrots, squash, dark green leafy vegetables, sweet red peppers, and fruits like apricots, grapefruit, papaya, mangos, and cantaloupe are rich in vitamin A. [15] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The daily dietary requirement of vitamin A for women is 700 mcg and 900 mcg for men. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Get your vitamin C.
steps.content: Get your vitamin C. Take vitamin C when you take an iron supplement to bring about a synergistic effect. This is because vitamin C helps your body absorb more iron, increasing red blood cell production. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Studies show that taking 200 mg of vitamin C per day with 100 mg of iron may improve iron absorption in the body. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source However, take precautions when taking iron, since high doses of iron supplements can be harmful to the body. [19] X Research source Be cautious when taking high doses of vitamin C since it can increase your risk of kidney stones. [20] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The highest daily intake likely to pose no risks is 2,000 mg per day. [21] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Get your daily exercise
steps.content: Get your daily exercise . Exercise is good for everyone, including those with low red blood cell (RBC) count, because it has both physical and mental benefits. [22] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It keeps you healthy and is recommended to avoid acquiring certain diseases and illnesses. [23] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Aerobic exercises, such as jogging, running, and swimming are best, though all exercise is good. [24] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Exercise has an important role in red blood cell production. When you do vigorous exercises, you get tired and sweat a lot, causing the hemoglobin in your body to release more oxygen and increase oxygen delivery to your muscles. This process stimulates the production of red blood cells and hemoglobin. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Kick the bad habits.
steps.content: Kick the bad habits. If you're concerned about your red blood cell (RBC) count, it's best to quit smoking and avoid drinking alcohol . Kicking these habits will also improve your overall health, too. [26] X Research source Cigarette smoking can interrupt blood flow, since it damages blood vessels and causes plaque build up in the arteries. [27] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source It also prevents proper blood circulation and lowers the amount of oxygen delivered throughout the body. [28] X Trustworthy Source Purdue Online Writing Lab Trusted resource for writing and citation guidelines Go to source On the other hand, excessive alcohol consumption can damage the bone marrow, reducing red blood cell (RBC) production and producing defective RBCs. [29] X Research source

steps.title: Get a blood transfusion if necessary.
steps.content: Get a blood transfusion if necessary. If your RBC count is still low and food and supplements do not help, a blood transfusion may be an option. You can talk to your primary doctor and have a diagnostic test given. [30] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source They may run a complete blood count (CBC) test to measure the number of RBCs you have in your body. [31] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your hemoglobin level is below 8 g/dL, they may recommend a transfusion. [32] X Trustworthy Source American Cancer Society Nonprofit devoted to promoting cancer research, education, and support Go to source Normal range of RBCs is 3.6 to 5 million cells per mcL for females and 4.2 to 5.4 million cells per mcL for males. [33] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source If you have a very low RBC count, a doctor may tell you to undergo a blood transfusion of packed red blood cell (PRBC). [34] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Get a routine physical assessment.
steps.content: Get a routine physical assessment. Visiting your doctor is one of the best ways to know how your RBCs are doing. Additional tests may be required to rule out any underlying condition that is causing a low RBC count. [35] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It’s best to see your physician regularly. An annual physical check-up is a healthy habit. [36] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you have been told you have a low RBC count, take the above tips to heart. Make lifestyle and diet changes to up your count and revisit your doctor. Your levels can normalize without medication or procedures. [37] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Know the basics of red blood cells.
steps.content: Know the basics of red blood cells. Around 40-45% of human body cells are red blood cells, or erythrocytes. [38] X Research source These RBCs are produced in the bone marrow, at a rate of approximately 2 million red blood cells per second. [39] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Erythrocytes circulate in the body for up to 120 days. [40] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source It takes 4-6 weeks to replace RBCs, which is why you can only donate blood once every 8 weeks (56 days). [41] X Research source Men have an average of 4.7 to 6.1 million RBCs/mcL, while women have an average of 4.2 to 5.4 million RBCs/mcL. [42] X Trustworthy Source University of California San Francisco Health Center Research hospital associated with UCSF, a leading medical university, providing innovative patient care and public health resources Go to source If you are a regular blood donor, you may have noticed that men can donate more often than women. [43] X Research source

steps.title: Know how hemoglobin works in the blood.
steps.content: Know how hemoglobin works in the blood. The iron-rich protein known as hemoglobin is the main component of red blood cells. [44] X Research source It is responsible for the red color of blood, and it contains iron, allowing it to carry oxygen throughout your body. [45] X Research source Each hemoglobin molecule has four iron atoms, each of which binds to 1 oxygen molecule with 2 oxygen atoms. [46] X Research source The normal hemoglobin level is 14 to 18 g/dL in men and 12 to 16 g/dL in women. [47] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Understand the role of red blood cells.
steps.content: Understand the role of red blood cells. Red blood cells play an important role in transporting oxygen-rich blood from the lungs to the tissues and cells. RBCs have cell membranes composed of lipids and proteins, which are essential for maintaining cellular function throughout the body. [48] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source In addition, red blood cells aid in the removal of carbon dioxide. They contain the carbonic anhydrase enzyme, which allows a reaction of water and carbon dioxide to form carbonic acid and separate hydrogen and bicarbonate ions. [49] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Hydrogen ions bind with hemoglobin and bicarbonate ions enter the plasma. Approximately 75% of carbon dioxide is transported in the red blood cells, while 25% of carbon dioxide is in the plasma. [50] X Research source
